channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ireland, Accused of Giving Tax Breaks to Multinationals, Plans an Even Lower Rate
item.description: The country will cut its 12.5 percent corporate tax rate in half for revenues pegged to patents and other intellectual property.
item.dc:creator: DOUGLAS DALBY and MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: Michael Noonan, the Irish finance minister, has long said that his country does not engage in “tax malpractice.”

item.title: Q&A: Turkey and the Aftermath of the Ankara Bombing
item.description: A correspondent discusses the deadly attack, the president’s response and the country’s political situation as snap parliamentary elections approach.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Taliban Withdraw From Kunduz After Days of Fighting
item.description: The insurgents held the city for 15 days, destroying government offices, hunting down opponents and allowing prisoners to escape the city’s prisons.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: A man injured in a rocket attack by the Taliban on Tuesday in Ghazni, the same day the insurgents announced a withdrawal from Kunduz.

item.title: Britain Pushes for Release of Grandfather Facing 350 Lashes in Saudi Arabia
item.description: The case of the grandfather, who was arrested after the Saudi authorities found alcohol in his car, has become a matter of geopolitical controversy.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain plans to make a personal appeal to the Saudi government to try to secure the release of Karl Andree.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Paul U. Unschuld on Reconciling Chinese and Western Medicine
item.description: A leading scholar of the history and ideas that underlie Chinese medicine discusses Tu Youyou’s Nobel Prize and how Chinese officials view their country’s medical heritage.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Myanmar Government Seeks to Calm Fears of Election Postponement
item.description: After the head of the election commission proposed delaying the vote, causing an outcry of suspicion, the government said the Nov. 8 date was unchanged.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER and WAI MOE
item.media:description: U Tin Aye, chairman of the election commission, spoke to journalists after meeting with political parties in Naypyidaw, Myanmar, on Tuesday.

item.title: Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 Most Likely Hit by Russian-Made Missile, Inquiry Says
item.description: The findings support a theory that the flight was shot down by Russian-backed separatists. Investigators also faulted Ukraine for not closing the airspace.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: The crash site of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 near the settlement of Grabovo, Ukraine, last year.

item.title: Mortar Shells Strike Near Russian Embassy in Syria
item.description: Two explosions came as crowds of Syrians gathered to show support for Russian airstrikes, but there were no immediate reports of casualties.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Syrians rallied outside the Russian Embassy in Damascus on Tuesday in support of Russia’s new campaign of airstrikes.

item.title: 4 Attacks by Palestinians Leave 3 Dead in Israel
item.description: The assaults were the most intense eruption so far in two weeks of escalating violence that has alarmed the country and flummoxed its security forces.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Emergency crew members removed the body of a Palestinian assailant after an attack on a bus in Jerusalem on Tuesday.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The End of Angela Merkel’s Irony
item.description: Chancellor Merkel is becoming bolder and more forthright about her vision for the country. What does that mean for the rest of us Germans?
item.dc:creator: ANNA SAUERBREY
item.media:description: Angela Merkel in New Delhi last week.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: A Land China Loves and Hates
item.description: When it comes to the U.S., many Chinese are schizophrenic: It is an imperialistic bully, and a great place to live.
item.dc:creator: MURONG XUECUN

item.title: Iran’s Parliament Backs Details of Nuclear Deal
item.description: The move paved the way for restrictions on the country’s nuclear program in exchange for the lifting of economic sanctions.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif of Iran, center, during a parliamentary session in Tehran on Tuesday.

item.title: Park Geun-hye of South Korea Defends Move to Issue State History Textbooks
item.description: The president argued that the government’s aim was partly to prevent the country from ever again being dominated by a foreign power.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Opposition lawmakers in Seoul, South Korea, protesting a government plan to introduce a state-issued textbook for use in middle and high schools.

item.title: Okinawa Governor Revokes Permission for Construction of U.S. Base
item.description: The decision is the latest setback for a 20-year effort by Japanese and American military planners to move the base from its current location.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:credit: Koji Harada/Kyodo News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters on Tuesday scuffling with the police as they try to demonstrate outside Camp Schwab, an existing American base in Okinawa in southern Japan.

item.title: Australia Proposes Extending Antiterror Controls to People as Young as 14
item.description: The government wants to lower the minimum age at which a court may restrict a person’s movement or communications.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Afghan ISIS Branch Makes Inroads in Battle Against Taliban
item.description: Islamic State victories against the Taliban have not weakened the overall insurgency, but have mostly inflicted more chaos and misery upon Afghan civilians.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: Afghan soldiers firing a field gun during an offensive against Islamic State militants in Nangarhar Province last month.

item.title: 여호와의 증인, 병역 거부 이유로 한국에서 주홍글씨 낙인
item.description: 전세계에 수감된 양심적 병역거부자의 90% 이상이 한국에 수감 중인 여호와의 증인 신도라고 한다.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: 찬송가를 부르고 있는 여호와의 증인 신도 김민환씨(오른쪽). 김씨는 양심적 병역거부로 징역을 살았다.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: A Road to Damascus, via Moscow
item.description: America’s best hope of beating the Islamic State is a­ coalition with Russia.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: GORDON ADAMS and STEPHEN M. WALT
item.media:credit: Alexander Kots/Komsomolskaya Pravda, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Syrian Army soldiers in Hama, Syria, on Sunday.

item.title: Hong Kong Journal: Hong Kong Is Losing Its Neon Glow
item.description: In decline since the 1990s, the city’s neon signs are being eclipsed by ones made of LEDs, which lack neon’s warmth but are brighter and less expensive to maintain.
item.dc:creator: CRYSTAL TSE
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lau Wan, a sign maker in Hong Kong. Mr. Lau, who has been making neon signs by hand since 1957, says he fears his craft is dying.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Joshua Wong Seeks Lower Age Limit for Hong Kong Candidates
item.description: Mr. Wong, who turns 19 on Tuesday, is seeking to lower the minimum age for candidates to the Legislative Council to 18, from 21.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Joshua Wong, the student activist who spearheaded pro-democracy demonstrations in Hong Kong last year.
